Award.AwardTitle: Icing Physics Studies Pertinent to Wind Turbine Icing and De/Anti-icing

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1064196

Hu

Wind turbine icing represents the most significant threat to the integrity of wind turbines in cold weather. In this proposed research, an integrated experimental, numerical and theoretical study is carried out to quantify important micro-physical processes pertinent to the wind turbine icing phenomena. More specially, detailed experimental investigations are conducted to examine the transient behavior of unfrozen surface water film and rivulet flows on ice accreting surfaces to elucidate underlying physics for more accurate prediction of ice formation and accretion on the surfaces of wind turbine blades. Computational and theoretical investigations, which include numerical simulations of the three-phase nonlinear coupling between air, water and ice as well as comprehensive asymptotic modeling of those processes, are also conducted to coordinate with the experimental work.

Intellectual Merit: By elucidating the underlying physics, the proposed research would significantly improve our understanding about the important micro-physical processes pertinent to wind turbine icing phenomena. A better understanding of the important micro-physical processes will enable us to improve current ice accretion models for more accurate prediction of ice formation and ice accretion on wind turbine blades. The new findings derived from the proposed research can also be used to develop effective and robust anti-/de-icing strategies tailored for wind turbine icing applications to ensure safer and more efficient operation of wind turbines in cold weather.

Broader Impact: The proposed research program will be incorporated into the Iowa State's curricula (both undergraduate and graduate). The findings derived from the proposed research will be disseminated broadly to contribute to the knowledge base of icing physics and wind turbine technology. Female and minority students will be recruited to work on the proposed research to promote the participation of underrepresented groups in science and engineering. Various outreach activities are planned to impart K-12 teachers and students, and by extension, the public at large, a greater awareness of renewable energy and wind turbine technology and their importance to our daily lives.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wind turbine icing represents the most significant threat to the integrity of wind turbines in cold weather. The objective of this research project is to quantify important micro-physical processes pertinent to the wind turbine icing phenomena for safer and more efficient operation of wind turbines in atmospheric icing conditions. More specially, a novel, lifetime-based molecular tagging thermometry (MTT) technique has been developed to quantify the unsteady heat transfer and phase changing process within micro-sized icing water droplets impinging onto frozen cold test plates to elucidate the underlying physics pertinent to the ice formation and ice accreting process as water droplets impinge onto icing wind turbine blades. The lifetime-based MTT technique has been applied to examine the transient behavior of unfrozen surface water film and rivulet flows on ice accreting surfaces, to gain insight of the underlying physics of surface water transport in order to improve current ice accretion models for more accurate prediction of glaze ice accretion and thermally protected surfaces on wind turbine blades. The effects of the blade surface properties (e.g., roughness and thermal conductivity) on ice formation and ice accretion process has been evaluated for the development of effective and robust anti/de-icing strategies tailored for wind turbine icing applications. Computational and theoretical investigations, which include numerical simulations of the three-phase nonlinear coupling between air, water and ice as well as comprehensive asymptotic modeling of those processes, have also be conducted to coordinate with the experimental work. The experimental, numerical and theoretical investigations have been integrated to provide the foundation for the development of comprehensive engineering simulation tools and design strategies for wind turbine icing mitigation and protection.

The findings derived from this research project have been disseminated broadly to contribute to the knowledge base of icing physics and wind turbine anti-/de-icing technology. In addition to educating and training graduate and undergraduate students to carry out the proposed research, this research program was also incorporated into the curricula (both undergraduate and graduate) to enhance Iowa State University’s educational and research infrastructures.

A new airfoil icing experiment module was developed and added to the existing undergraduate and graduate aerodynamics and propulsion courses (AerE344 and AerE545) to augment concepts and fundamental principles introduced in aerodynamics and propulsion classes and to stimulate students’ interests in thermal-fluid science. By leveraging Iowa State’s PWSE, LEAD and PERUSE programs, 3 female and minority students were recruited to work on this research project to promote the participation of underrepresented groups in science and engineering.  “Renewable Energy and Wind Turbine Technology” seminars and demonstration experiments have been developed to impart K-12 teachers and students, and by extension, the public at large, a greater awareness of renewable energy and wind turbine technology and their importance to our daily lives.  In summary, this project did bring together university professors and K-12 teachers with graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students in a multi-level learning experience infused with the excitement of discovery. 


Last Modified: 07/17/2016
Modified by: Hui Hu

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Wind turbine icing represents the most significant threat to the integrity of wind turbines in cold weather. The objective of this research project is to quantify important micro-physical processes pertinent to the wind turbine icing phenomena for safer and more efficient operation of wind turbines in atmospheric icing conditions. More specially, a novel, lifetime-based molecular tagging thermometry (MTT) technique has been developed to quantify the unsteady heat transfer and phase changing process within micro-sized icing water droplets impinging onto frozen cold test plates to elucidate the underlying physics pertinent to the ice formation and ice accreting process as water droplets impinge onto icing wind turbine blades. The lifetime-based MTT technique has been applied to examine the transient behavior of unfrozen surface water film and rivulet flows on ice accreting surfaces, to gain insight of the underlying physics of surface water transport in order to improve current ice accretion models for more accurate prediction of glaze ice accretion and thermally protected surfaces on wind turbine blades. The effects of the blade surface properties (e.g., roughness and thermal conductivity) on ice formation and ice accretion process has been evaluated for the development of effective and robust anti/de-icing strategies tailored for wind turbine icing applications. Computational and theoretical investigations, which include numerical simulations of the three-phase nonlinear coupling between air, water and ice as well as comprehensive asymptotic modeling of those processes, have also be conducted to coordinate with the experimental work. The experimental, numerical and theoretical investigations have been integrated to provide the foundation for the development of comprehensive engineering simulation tools and design strategies for wind turbine icing mitigation and protection. The findings derived from this research project have been disseminated broadly to contribute to the knowledge base of icing physics and wind turbine anti-/de-icing technology. In addition to educating and training graduate and undergraduate students to carry out the proposed research, this research program was also incorporated into the curricula (both undergraduate and graduate) to enhance Iowa State UniversityÆs educational and research infrastructures. A new airfoil icing experiment module was developed and added to the existing undergraduate and graduate aerodynamics and propulsion courses (AerE344 and AerE545) to augment concepts and fundamental principles introduced in aerodynamics and propulsion classes and to stimulate studentsÆ interests in thermal-fluid science. By leveraging Iowa StateÆs PWSE, LEAD and PERUSE programs, 3 female and minority students were recruited to work on this research project to promote the participation of underrepresented groups in science and engineering. "Renewable Energy and Wind Turbine Technology" seminars and demonstration experiments have been developed to impart K-12 teachers and students, and by extension, the public at large, a greater awareness of renewable energy and wind turbine technology and their importance to our daily lives. In summary, this project did bring together university professors and K-12 teachers with graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students in a multi-level learning experience infused with the excitement of discovery.
